description: The mansion was built in 1789 by Elias Blackwood, a wealthy and ruthless industrialist.
Elias’s first wife, Isolde, vanished during a grand ball in 1795, leaving behind only a trail of bloodstains on the dance floor.
Elias remarried Lilith, a woman rumored to practice dark magic, in 1802.
Elias died in 1810 under mysterious circumstances, found clutching a locket with a portrait of an unknown woman.
The mansion passed to Elias’s son, Victor Blackwood, who was known for his cruelty and obsession with the occult.
Victor’s daughter, Elara, drowned in the mansion’s fountain in 1837. Witnesses claimed she was pulled under by invisible hands.
The mansion was abandoned in 1850 after Victor’s death, as locals believed it was cursed.
A fire in 1872 destroyed the west wing, killing three firefighters. The cause was never determined.
In 1899, the mansion was bought by Dr. Alistair Graves, a scientist who conducted secret experiments on the paranormal.
Dr. Graves disappeared in 1905, leaving behind journals filled with sketches of monstrous creatures and frantic notes.
The grand staircase sometimes leads to a hallway that doesn’t exist, vanishing when followed.
Whispers echo through the walls, especially in the master bedroom, even when no one is there.
A portrait of Isolde Blackwood occasionally 'bleeds' from the eyes, staining the floor below.
A piano in the ballroom plays by itself at midnight, always the same haunting melody.
Dark, humanoid shadows move through the corridors, disappearing when approached.
Certain rooms become freezing cold for no reason, even in the middle of summer.
Furniture rearranges itself overnight, sometimes forming strange, occult symbols.
Blood-curdling screams are heard from the cellar, but no one is ever found there.
Candles in the dining hall float in mid-air during storms, casting eerie, shifting shadows.
A door in the east wing is always locked, but no key has ever been found to open it.
Isolde Blackwood wanders the halls in her ballgown, weeping and searching for something—or someone.
Elara Blackwood appears near the fountain, her dress dripping wet, staring silently at visitors.
A faceless maid is seen polishing silverware that vanishes when she stops.
Dr. Alistair Graves mutters equations and stares at invisible experiments in his old laboratory.
A shadow child giggles and hides in the walls, sometimes tugging on visitors’ sleeves.
A weeping woman in black is often seen in the library, crying over a book that burns when touched.
A tall, gaunt figure stands at the end of hallways, watching visitors with hollow eyes.
A laughing man in a top hat is heard cackling maniacally in the ballroom, but no one is there.
The sound of a crying baby echoes through the nursery, but no child is ever found.
A silent butler serves invisible guests in the dining hall, offering plates of rotten food.
Isolde’s locket contains a portrait of a woman who is not Isolde, hinting at a hidden affair or betrayal.
The Blackwood Journal is filled with Elias’s ramblings about 'the thing in the walls.'
A bloodstained letter from Lilith warns Elias about 'the ritual,' but the rest is illegible.
A silver key was found in the cellar, but no lock in the mansion fits it.
A cursed mirror in the master bedroom shows reflections of people who aren’t there—sometimes screaming.
A music box plays a haunting melody when wound, but its origin is unknown.
An Ouija board in Dr. Graves’s lab is covered in frantic messages, some written in an unknown language.
The Blackwood Family Bible has names crossed out in red ink, including Isolde’s.
A collection of porcelain dolls in the nursery are each missing an eye, and their heads turn to follow visitors.
Strange symbols carved into the cellar walls glow faintly at night, pulsing like a heartbeat.
Anyone who spends a night in the mansion will die within a year, according to local folklore.
On the anniversary of Isolde’s disappearance, the mansion lights up, and ghostly figures dance inside.
A statue in the garden weeps blood every full moon, staining the grass below.
A bridge on the mansion’s grounds disappears at dawn, stranding those who cross it.
A black carriage arrives at the mansion at midnight, but no one is ever inside.
The mansion’s grandfather clock chimes 13 times on the hour, every hour.
A room in the attic is said to contain a portal to another world, but the door is always locked.
The stone lions at the entrance come to life at night, guarding the mansion from intruders.
A traveler who stayed in the mansion in 1923 was found the next morning, aged 50 years.
Ghostly figures are seen dining in the ballroom, but the food on their plates is always rotten.
